title: How to Read Roman Numerals: Learning Guide for Beginners

steps.title: Basic Symbols
steps.content: Basic Symbols Roman numerals use 7 letters—I, V, X, L, C, D, and M—to represent numerical values. These values are added or subtracted to make a number based on how these symbols are arranged. Here are their values: [1] X Research source I = 1 V = 5 X = 10 L = 50 C = 100 D = 500 M = 1000

steps.title: Numbers 1-9
steps.content: Numbers 1-9 The digits in the ones place are made by adding or subtracting the numerals I (1) and V (5). When you see multiples of a numeral in a row, add them together (II = 1+1 = 2). When a smaller value numeral is placed after a numeral, add them together (VI = 5+1 = 6). When a smaller value numeral is placed before a larger value numeral, subtract the smaller value from the larger one (IX = 10 - 1 = 9). [2] X Research source I = 1 II = 2 III = 3 IV = 4 V = 5 VI = 6 VII = 7 VIII = 8 IX = 9

steps.title: Numbers 10-90
steps.content: Numbers 10-90 The digits in the tens place are made by adding or subtracting the numerals X (10), L (50), and C (100). These numbers follow the same addition and subtraction rules as the digits in the ones place. [3] X Research source X = 10 XX = 20 XXX = 30 XL = 40 L = 50 LX = 60 LXX = 70 LXXX = 80 XC = 90

steps.title: Numbers 100-900
steps.content: Numbers 100-900 Digits in the hundreds place are made by adding or subtracting the numerals C 9100), D (500), and M (1000), following the same placement rules as the ones and tens place. [4] X Research source C = 100 CC = 200 CCC = 300 CD = 400 D = 500 DC = 600 DCC = 700 DCCC = 800 CM = 900

steps.title: You can't have more than three of the same symbol in a row.
steps.content: You can't have more than three of the same symbol in a row. When you place the same symbols together, just add their values. Normally, the maximum number of consecutive same symbols is three. Repeated symbols are always added together. [5] X Research source For example: II = 2 (1+1 = 2) XXX = 30 (10+10+10 = 30) Note: The symbols V, L, and D are never repeated.

steps.title: Smaller symbol values placed after large symbol values are added.
steps.content: Smaller symbol values placed after large symbol values are added. Similar to the above rule, just add their values together. Remember, the numeral must have the larger symbol value first for this to work. Here's how you do it: [6] X Research source XI = 11 (10+1 = 11) MCL = 1150 (1000+100+50 = 1150)

steps.title: Smaller symbols placed before larger ones are subtracted from the larger.
steps.content: Smaller symbols placed before larger ones are subtracted from the larger. In this case, you subtract the smaller value from the larger value. Here's how you do it: [7] X Research source For example: IV = 4 (5-1 = 4) CM = 900 (1000=100 = 900)

steps.title: A numeral with a bar over the top of it is multiplied by 1000.
steps.content: A numeral with a bar over the top of it is multiplied by 1000. To write very large numbers, add a bar (called a vinculum ) over any numeral to indicate that it’s multiplied by 1000. For example, to write 1 million, you’d place a bar over the numeral M (1000x1000 = 1 million). [8] X Research source V̅ = 5000 X̅ = 10,000 L̅ = 50,000 C̅ = 100,000 D̅ = 500,000 M = 1,000,000 It’s rare to see the numeral I with a bar since M already represents 1000, but it does come up in large compound numbers (for example: I̅V̅ = 5000-1000 = 4000). Note: For some large numbers, you can repeat numerals more than 3 times. For example, 5 million could be represented by MMMMM since there is no larger symbol than M (1,000). [9] X Research source Alternative: Rarely, you’ll see a numeral with 2 bars over the top of it. This indicates that the value of the numeral is multiplied by 1 million. [10] X Research source So, another way to write 5 million could be an M with 2 bars on top.

Example: Write 2987 in Roman numerals. To convert this number into Roman numerals, we’ll find the numerals for each digit place (thousands, hundreds, tens, and ones) and write them in order: [11] X Research source Thousands: MM (1000+1000 = 2000) Hundreds: CM (1000-100 = 900) Tens: LXXX (50+10+10+10 = 80) Ones: VII (5+1+1 = 7) All together, 2987 is written as MMCMLXXXVII

Example: Write MCMXCIV as a number. To convert a Roman numeral into a number , we’ll examine the pattern of large and small numeral values to determine which numbers go in the thousands, hundreds, tens, and ones places: Thousands: M = 1000 Hundreds: CM = 900 (1000-100 = 900). Since C is a smaller value than M, we know that it must be subtracted from M to form a separate digit (and not added to the previous M). Tens: XC = 90 (100-10 = 90) Ones: IV = 4 (5-1 = 4) All together, MCMXCIV is 1,994.

steps.title: Use a mnemonic device to memorize the value order of the symbols.
steps.content: Use a mnemonic device to memorize the value order of the symbols. If you have a hard time remembering what goes where, just try this simple one: “ M y D ear C at L oves X tra V itamins I ntensely.” This helps you memorize the order of the numerals from largest to smallest. [12] X Research source Alternatively, to remember them in ascending order, use “ I V alue X ylophones L ike C ows D o M ilk.”

steps.title: Check your work with an online converter tool.
steps.content: Check your work with an online converter tool. If you want to make sure you converted a number correctly, check out some online converters to see if you're on track. Try this conversion tool from RomanNumerals.org—just enter the numerals or numbers you want to convert and click the “Convert” button to check your results!

steps.title: Roman numerals were used to count and number items in the Roman Empire.
steps.content: Roman numerals were used to count and number items in the Roman Empire. The earliest known Roman numerals showed up between 900 and 800 BCE and were based on finger counting. For example, the numeral I represents one finger, or the number 1. The numeral V means 5 because it resembles the “V” shape made between your thumb nd index finger. The numeral X is believed to represent two open hands, or two Vs touching at their points. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Roman numerals had disadvantages that made them inconvenient to use.
steps.content: Roman numerals had disadvantages that made them inconvenient to use. For one, there is no Roman numeral to represent the number 0. There’s also no easy way to write fractions using Roman numerals either. Both of these disadvantages make it hard to do complex math and hindered the Romans’ ability to create and use a universally understood numerical system for trading. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Roman numerals fell out of use in the Middle Ages.
steps.content: Roman numerals fell out of use in the Middle Ages. Since Rome had ruled many territories in Europe, these areas continued to use Roman numerals long after the Western Empire collapsed in 476 AD. Around 1300 AD, the Hindu-Arabic numerals we use today replaced Roman numerals throughout most of Europe. [15] X Research source Hindu-Arabic numerals made it easier to do complex calculations. In fact, it’s believed that Europe’s use of Roman numerals contributed to its mathematical “Dark Ages” compared to Middle Eastern and Indian cultures, which made great mathematical strides during the Middle Ages. Today, Roman numerals are used mostly for aesthetic purposes in places like watches and clocks, building cornerstones, movie credits, the titles of monarchs and popes, and the titles of major events like the Olympics or Super Bowl. [16] X Research source
